Award.AwardTitle: The Effects of Emotion Regulation Strategies when Contending with Discrimination

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Discrimination is unfair negative treatment due to societal group membership, such as race, class, sexual orientation, and gender. Discrimination is a stressor that can harm mental and physical health, and opportunities for work and promotions. Previous research has found that discrimination can impair performance on cognitive tasks, which can lead to negative emotions, such as anxiety, despair, and anger. The present research examines novel approaches to regulate emotional reactions to discrimination. These approaches stem from research suggesting that reflecting on negative life events from a third-person, distanced point of view rather than from a personal, immersed point of view leads to better emotional outcomes. This complements findings with well-known models of emotion regulation, which suggest that distanced processing of emotional content lead to more positive outcomes than immersed processing. Dr. Jennifer Richeson at Yale University, examines multiple consequences of contending with experiences of group-based discrimination from a distanced versus immersed perspective. The project also tests a novel strategy to create positive emotional responses by having participants reflect on past discrimination that reveals the ways they or their group may have become stronger or benefitted from having had discrimination experiences in the past. Creating such redemption narratives about stressful events has been found to enhance well-being and may hold promise to promote well-being in the face of discrimination.

The proposed work integrates research from affective, emotion regulation science, and social psychology to consider processes that give rise to the ill effects of discrimination. The research proposes that compared to holding an immersed perspective, holding a more distanced perspective enhances emotion regulation and emotional outcomes. Experiments examine the influence of different emotion-regulation strategies on emotional reactions, physiological arousal, and cognitive functioning, as well as the motivation to act on behalf of the group that has faced discrimination. The proposed seven experiments examine these dynamics among different societal groups that often face discrimination (e.g., racial/ethnic minorities, women), and an experiment examines the role of creating a redemption narrative on reducing some of the negative mental and physical outcomes of discrimination. Consequently, the results of this project are poised to unearth novel insights to inform current understanding of the effects of discrimination on individual well-being and societal social cohesion.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes

 

Intellectual Merit

The proposed research offers a model of the effects of discrimination on psychological health and well-being, highlighting the role of emotion regulation. Specifically, this work investigated the role of different emotion regulation strategies in shaping the effects of discrimination experiences on outcomes for the individuals, such as their own emotional experiences, as well as outcomes for the group, such as individuals’ interest in collective action. Members of different marginalized social groups (e.g., racial minorities, women, sexual minorities) were either exposed to instances of group-relevant discrimination and/or asked to re-live their own past experiences from either a relatively distanced (objective) perspective, a relatively immersed perspective, or, rather, to engage in a “redemptive” form of reappraisal of the event. The effects of these different emotion regulation strategies upon exposure to and/or re-living discriminatory events on participants’ emotions, cognitive functioning, and behavioral tendencies regarding collective-action were examined.

As expected, both experiencing and re-living discrimination yielded negative outcomes for psychological well-being. Even reflecting on past experiences of discrimination significantly impacted participants’ emotional well-being. And, while we found minimal evidence that distancing resulted in more positive affective and cognitive outcomes than immersion when people re-lived their own experiences, there was some evidence that distancing was beneficial when exposed to group-based discrimination in general. The most novel finding of this work, however, is the potential for generating redemption narratives about past experiences with group-based discrimination— for instance, re-thinking the value of these negative events in terms of lessons learned— to alleviate the affective burden of re-living those experiences. Across a number of experiments, we found that generating a redemption narrative about past experiences of sexism, for instance, resulted in less negative affect among women, compared with re-living those experiences from an immersed, first-person perspective, from a more distanced, third-person perspective, as well as compared with efforts to simply distract the self from the experience with another task. Similar results emerged for Black Americans who generate redemption narratives regarding past experiences of racial discrimination, compared with immersion and distraction.

Taken together, these findings reveal the possibility that certain emotion regulation strategies are differentially effective in mitigating the negative effects of experiencing discrimination. Further, the research reveals the promise of integrating theory and research from affective science and personality psychology with work on social stigma to advance the psychological science of experiencing discrimination.

 

Broader Impact

 Discrimination, unfair negative treatment due to one’s race, class, sexual orientation, gender, or other social identity, is a stressor that negatively impacts psychological well-being. In order to develop interventions to mitigate these negative effects, it is important to understand the pathways that give rise to them. This research aimed to advance such understanding and our findings are likely also to shed light on psychological component processes that contribute to persistent disparities (e.g., in health, wealth, achievement) between members of stigmatized and dominant groups. In addition, the project advanced the careers of 3 trainees (2 PhD students and 1 postdoctoral fellow) from underrepresented racial backgrounds, as well as numerous undergraduate students from traditionally disadvantaged groups, all of whom will have a role in the production of the proposed research. Through both its production and dissemination, therefore, this project met NSF’s call for science with the potential for broad societal impact.
